CHS senior Emily Wright named CTE Best of the Best

Congratulations to CHS senior Emily Wright. Emily was named Clio's CTE Best of the Best. According to Mr. Thompson, Emily is a tremendous representation of Clio’s Career and Technical Education program. She has excelled in many CTE courses and served as general manager of our school store.

Emily is very active within our school. She successfully juggles all of her activities with integrity. Emily also is dual enrolled at the University of Michigan-Flint and is involved in athletics. She has a work ethic that enables her to be successful in her busy schedule. She also has placed at the DECA State Conference and qualified for the International Career Development Conference this school year. Congratulations!

post_text:
Clio High senior Lillian Miller among top 5 in Youth Entrepreneurship Pitch Contest

Clio High School continues to produce young people ready for success in today’s world as for the second year in a row, a CHS student has placed in the top five in the Youth Entrepreneurship Pitch Contest, created by the GISD and the Mott Foundation. This year that honor went to Lillian Miller.

Lillian created a video promoting her business idea centered around a mobile beauty salon (called Pre-Glam) and used skills obtained from Ron Weaver’s Introduction to Business class and Tyler Thompson's Marketing class.

“She did a great job,” declared Mr. Weaver, “and was only 0.01 points from taking first place.”

In addition to the $200 for winning our district contest and then an additional $300 for the county top five placing, Lillian will receive a certificate and her name will appear on billboards, with the other top five winners, around Genesee County. Congratulations Lillian!

Clio High’s first ever snow sculpting team shines in Frankenmuth
Fielding its first ever team to participate in the high school division of the ice sculpting competition at Frankenmuth’s SnowFest, Clio placed 10th out of 20 teams Friday.
“We were invited back for next year's Winterfest!,” declared art teacher and coach Tina Kennamer. “We did great and learned so much! We worked through disappointments with the weather, broken features, on the spot composition changes...hot vanilla lattes turning cold. I'm so proud!”
Members of the team were Abecca Frank, Alexis Urban, Olivia Chojnacki, and Paige Adkins. Follow this link to lots more photos: https://photos.app.goo.gl/LfE8GHKzpX2zdidT8

Old CCHS building closed but still serving community

It was constructed in 1928 as an elementary school and has served the community ever since, housing a host of programs, grade levels, and more over the years. Recently closed and earmarked for demolition before the end of the year, the building known as Clio Community High School was still serving the community this week as the Genesee County Sheriff’s Department used it for training. They practiced a variety of scenarios including an active shooter, breaching a locked door, emergency medical technics and more. They were very grateful to have such a facility to conduct this realistic training, helping them be more prepared in the event of a real emergency situation. The district was happy to offer the building for these purposes and appreciates the training and readiness of these first responders.

post_text:
Simms Chevrolet supports Mustang Football with $1,500 donation and test drive program

Clio varsity football received a financial shot in the arm last week from Simms Chevrolet as the dealership presented a $1,500 check to the program through the Chevrolet Youth Sports Community Involvement Program. Bruce Simms said the football program was selected because of the “sportsmanship and team effort” it shows.
Mustang head coach Capus Robinson expressed his appreciation to Simms for their continued support of the football program, the school, and the entire community.
The team will have the opportunity to earn even more money from a test drive event set for this Friday, 4 – 7 p.m. at the high school just prior to the final home football game. There will be several new cars available there and GM will donate additional money for each test drive taken, up to $500.

DECA wows at International Conference, brings home ‘DECA Glass’

Our DECA Chapter was very well represented at the International Career Development Conference held in Orlando, Florida.
Our members qualified to attend based on superior performances at the district and state levels.
This year Clio had 13 students compete for a chance to win the coveted DECA Glass. Our team of Cassidy Fortney, Ashley Wagner, and Ethan Webber (pictured here with Mr. Thompson) placed in the Top 5 for their Chapter Awards Project, earning them "DECA Glass!" We are very proud of our entire chapter.
Also attending the International Career Development Conference were: Cooper Lenzi, Lane Wright, Jacob Fagerstrom, Madison Fagerstrom, Cassidy Fortney, Ashley Nelson, Ashley Wagner, Teddy Benner, Karlee Balanowski, Zoey Campbell, Sadah Duvernois, Brooklyn Rushton, and Ethan Webber.
This trip was made possible by the generous support and contributions from the Clio Area Education Foundation. The chapter is so grateful for their generosity.

Three students from Carter Middle School in Clio have been named local winners in the 50th annual America & Me Essay Contest, sponsored by Farm Bureau Insurance.
The three students, who earned the first, second, and third place awards for their school, are Ashleigh Schriner, first, Vivian Talford, second, and Sydney Folcik, third. All three received award certificates for their achievement. As the school's first place winner, Ashleigh's name will also be engraved on a plaque for permanent display in the school.
Ashleigh's first place essay, which honors the woman who she views as her personal hero, Mrs. Lamb, now advances to the state level competition, from which the top ten essays in Michigan will be selected.
Pictured (l to r) are: Pat McGuire – agent sponsor, Ashleigh, Vivian, Sydney and CMS teacher and contest coordinator Kyle Hayden. Ashleigh is also pictured here with Mrs. Lamb.
